topic_seeds.description: Struggling with social situations and fear of judgment (relatively straightforward)
Considering or going through a career change

flaw_patterns.name: burying_the_lede
flaw_patterns.description: Real issue mentioned last or casually, buried under safer topics

flaw_patterns.name: rewriting_history
flaw_patterns.description: Remembers past events or statements differently

exchanges.user:
Hey. So been meaning to reach out. Work's been pretty stressful lately, like the usual deadlines and stuff. My manager's been riding me about project timelines which is whatever, I can handle that. 

But honestly the thing that's really getting to me is I went to my cousin's thing last weekend, you know, family gathering. And there were all these people I haven't seen in a while and I just... I don't know. I ended up sitting in the kitchen most of the time instead of being out there with everyone. My sister made some comment about me being antisocial and it just hit different this time. Like it bothered me more than usual. Don't think she meant anything by it but yeah. That's been on my mind.

Anyway how does this work? Like how often are we talking and what's the deal.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work stress:** Deadlines and manager pressure—sounds like background noise you've learned to manage. You're mentioning it, but it doesn't sound like the part that's really sticking with you.

**The family gathering:** This is the piece that landed heavier. You found yourself gravitating toward the kitchen instead of being out there with everyone, and when your sister called it out—even casually—it stung in a way it usually doesn't. I'm curious what that shift means. Has pulling away from groups been happening more lately, or was this party different somehow? And when she said "antisocial," what thought went through your head in that moment?

**How this works:** We talk async, like this—you message when something's on your mind, I respond, no set schedule. Some people check in weekly, some every few days, some when they need it. You set the pace. And you can bring anything: stuff that's actively bothering you, things you're trying to figure out, updates on how things are going. Whatever feels useful.

Sounds like the kitchen thing is sitting with you. Want to say more about what that was like?

That's exactly how it works. It won't feel profound, and yeah, it might feel silly at first, but you're creating space between you and the surveillance camera. The fact that it helped "a little" is actually significant—you're not aiming to make the thoughts disappear, just to stop treating them as truth. Keep experimenting with it.

She was doing that parent thing where they freeze you in the version of you they've always known, and it landed like she was closing a door on the possibility that you could be different. You didn't snap at her, you held it in, and now it's sitting in your body as irritability. What would it have felt like to say something in that moment? Not snapping, but just naming it—like, "I don't know if that's still true about me." I'm curious if the anger is partly at her for the box, and partly at yourself for not pushing back.
